title: Bismuth Carboxylates with Brucite- and Fluorite-Related Structures: Synthesis Structure and Properties
abstract: Bismuth carboxylates exhibiting a brucite-related layer and a fluorite-related structure have been synthesized and characterized. The possible role of lone pair of electrons of Bi
in the structure and properties has been evaluated.

, have been prepared by the reaction between bismuth nitrate and heterocyclic aromatic dicarboxylic acids, 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid, 4,5-imidazoledicarboxylic acid, and 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid, respectively, under hydrothermal conditions. The structures of all the compounds have linkages between Bi
and the corresponding dicarboxylate forming a simple molecular unit in

) can be realized in these structures. By utilizing the secondary interactions, one can correlate the structure of

to a Kagome-related one. The observation of such classical inorganic related structures in the bismuth carboxylates is noteworthy. Lewis acid catalytic studies on the formation of ketal suggest the possible participatory role of the lone pair of electrons. All the compounds are characterized employing elemental analysis, IR, UV–vis, and thermal studies.
text: Inorganic coordination polymers or metal–organic frameworks are an important family of compounds in the area of materials chemistry.

The compounds have interesting structures formed by the clever combination of inorganic coordination chemistry and organic functional groups. It is known that the rigid organic backbone in these compounds is crucial for many of its interesting physical and chemical properties such as catalysis, sorption, and separation.
The large number and the diversity observed in the structures of inorganic coordination polymers is a testimony for the continuing interest.
The majority of the compounds have been prepared employing either the transition metals or the lanthanides.
It is to be noted that the main group elements have not received much attention. Of the main group elements, Al,
have been investigated and appear to form interesting structures.
Bismuth, though part of the main group elements, has not been studied in sufficient detail. Bi
ions may be of interest due to the presence of its stereoactive lone pair of electrons.
compounds in open-framework phosphates suggest the possible structure-directing role for the lone pair of electrons.
Similar lone pair effects have also been observed in Sn
From the available structures of Bi

one finds reasonable evidence for the structure-directing role for the lone pair of electrons. The lone pair of electrons appears to participate in a structure-direction role, depending on the coordination environment around the Bi
One can rationalize this observation, rather naively, that low coordination would lead to nonspherical charge distribution around the Bi
cation resulting in the lone pair actively participating in a structure-directing role (hemi-directed).
Higher coordination, on the other hand, would result in steric hindrance as well as in a more uniform charge distribution around the Bi
cation leading to an inactive role for the lone pair of electrons (holo-directed).
It is clear that the nature and the role of the lone pair of electrons in Bi
carboxylates are interesting and there is considerable scope to investigate this further in other Bi

One of the advantages of inorganic coordination polymers is the formation of more open and porous structures, by employing subtle crystal engineering principles. The impetus to study the bismuth-based compounds would be to exploit the lone pair of electrons not only in structure direction but also in related properties such as catalysis. It would be preferable to have open structures in which the lone pair of electrons are freely accessible and available for manipulations. From the Pearson’s theory of hard–soft acids and bases, Bi
ions can be considered to be a borderline acid.
From the available structures in the literature, it appears that Bi

ion can bind fairly well with ligands possessing O and N donor atoms. Thus, one can expect to find the anions of amino polycarboxylic acid and polyamino carboxylic acids to form stable compounds with Bi
ions. The recent findings on the formation of coordination polymeric structure of Bi
In addition, the larger size of the Bi
ions would give coordination number higher than six in most of the compounds, which is also the observed behavior.
As part of a program to prepare new inorganic coordination polymers, we are interested in the reaction between heterocyclic aromatic carboxylic acids and Bi

, have one-, two-, and three-dimensional structure. In this paper, the synthesis, structure, and properties of the three compounds are presented.

Many inorganic coordination polymers have been investigated for their catalytic properties, as they exhibit Lewis acid behavior. One of the earliest works in this area is due to Fujitha and co-workers,
who established that the cadmium centers in [(Cd(4,4′-bpy)
were conducive for the cyanosilylation of imines. There are reports of similar Lewis acid behavior in some of the bismuth-containing compounds as well.
ion can be considered to be a borderline acid, according to Pearson’s theory of hard and soft acids and bases.

In addition, we wanted to explore the possible impact of the holo- or hemi-direction of the lone pair of electrons in heterogeneous catalysis. To this end, we examined the acetal formation as well as the esterification reactions employing the present compounds as Lewis acid catalysts (Scheme
). The experimental protocols employed for the acetal formation reaction are similar to that employed in the literature.

In a typical experiment, 0.05 mM bismuth carboxylate (catalyst) was suspended in 10 mL of toluene. Acetone (0.58 g, 10 mM) was added with ethylene glycol (0.62 g, 10 mM), and the entire mixture was stirred and heated at 60 °C for 24 h. The formation of the corresponding ketal was analyzed using
H NMR. From the studies, it became clear that the hemi-directed compound (
exhibits considerably more catalytic activity compared to the holo-directed compounds (

, respectively. The control experiments were carried out in the absence of the catalyst, which produced only 5–6% of the ketal. The esterification reaction was carried out by reacting equimolar quantities of ethanol, and acetic acid at 60 °C for one day.
The yield for this reaction was considerably less, but the reactivity trend appears to be the same as observed in the ketal formation reaction. The yield of the ester is as follows: 44% (
). The yields of the products were calculated from the
H NMR spectra. The catalytic studies carried out in the present studies are exploratory reactions, which establish the Lewis acid character of the bismuth carboxylates.
The synthesis, structure, and characterization of bismuth carboxylates of varying dimensionalities have been accomplished. The stabilization of brucite-related (

) structures in the present compounds are the first such observation in bismuth carboxylates. The importance of secondary interactions is revealing in the visualization of a pillared Kagome structure in
. The present studies also suggests that the stereoactive lone pair of electrons of Bi

ions have some effect in the Lewis acid catalytic behavior of the present compounds. The coordination flexibility of the central Bi ions, observed in the present compounds, suggests the possibility of forming many related phases under suitable experimental conditions.

Simulated and experimental PXRD patterns, TGA curves, IR spectra, UV–vis spectra, photoluminescence spectra, bond angles of the compounds, asymmetric unit, bismuth and carboxylate connectivity diagram, other structural figures, and crystallographic data (CIF). Deconstructing the Crystal Structures of Metal-Organic Frameworks and Related Materials into Their Underlying Nets
A review.  Redn. of complex crystal structures of metal-org. frameworks and related materials to an underlying topol. is discussed.  An approach to identify vertices of underlying nets is presented.

Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro

A review.  Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli.  The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
A series of isoreticular chiral metal-organic frameworks as a tunable platform for asymmetric catalysis
Ma, Liqing; Falkowski, Joseph M.; Abney, Carter; Lin, Wenbin

Metal-org. frameworks, built by bridging metal ions with org. linkers, represent a new class of porous hybrid materials with attractive tunability in compns., structures and functions.  In particular, the mild conditions typically employed for their synthesis allow for the functionalization of their building blocks, and thus the rational design of novel materials.  Here the authors demonstrate the systematic design of eight mesoporous chiral metal-org. frameworks, with the framework formula [LCu2(solvent)2] (L is a chiral tetracarboxylate ligand derived from 1,1'-bi-2-naphthol), that have the same structures but channels of different sizes.  Chiral Lewis acid catalysts were generated by post-synthesis functionalization with Ti(OiPr)4, and the resulting materials proved to be highly active asym. catalysts for diethylzinc and alkynylzinc addns., which converted arom. aldehydes into chiral secondary alcs.  The enantioselectivities of these reactions can be modified by tuning the size of the channels, which alters the diffusion rates of the org. substrates.
Direct Crystallographic Observation of Catalytic Reactions inside the Pores of a Flexible Coordination Polymer
Das, Raj Kumar; Aijaz, Arshad; Sharma, Manish K.; Lama, Prem; Bharadwaj, Parimal K.

A new flexible porous coordination polymer (PCP), {[Gd2(L)3(DMF)4]·4DMF·3H2O}n (1), was synthesized under solvothermal condition by reacting [Gd(NO3)3]·6H2O with the ligand 2,6,2',6'-tetranitro-biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid (H2L).  Compd. 1 had a 3-dimensional coordination polymeric structure with two types of 1-dimensional channels (A and B) that were occupied by DMF and H2O mols.  When crystals of 1 were sep. exposed to vapors of various arom. aldehydes, either the lattice or both the lattice and metal-bound solvent mols. were replaced by aldehyde mols.  The aldehyde mols. inside the pores spontaneously underwent cyanosilylation and Knoevenagel condensation reactions upon exposure to vapors of trimethylsilyl cyanide and malononitrile, resp.  These reactions took place at ambient temp. and pressure.  Also, both the reactants and the products translocated from one cavity to another.  The products that occupied the cavity were expunged upon exposure to the vapors of an aldehyde.  Because crystallinity was maintained during these chem. transformations, direct crystallog. observation was possible.  Herein, confinement of the reactants inside the void spaces of the PCP led to the products; the authors also assessed catalytic activities of this PCP in bulk quantities.
Cyclohexane selective oxidation over metal-organic frameworks of MIL-101 family: superior catalytic activity and selectivity
Maksimchuk, Nataliya V.; Kovalenko, Konstantin A.; Fedin, Vladimir P.; Kholdeeva, Oxana A.

Mesoporous metal-org. frameworks Cr- and Fe-MIL-101 are highly efficient, true heterogeneous and recyclable catalysts for solvent-free selective oxidn. of cyclohexane with mol. oxygen and/or tert-Bu hydroperoxide under mild conditions.
Amino-functionalized basic catalysts with MIL-101 structure

Metal-org. framework (MOF) materials have only been scarcely explored for applications in heterogeneous catalysis in recent years.  In addn. to the use of MOFs as supports for the deposition of highly dispersed metal particles, the incorporation of active centers such as coordinatively unsatd. metal sites and the functionalization of the org. linkers with acidic or basic groups seem to be most promising.  In our contribution, three different MOFs carrying amino groups at their org. linkers, namely Fe-MIL-101-NH2 (SBET = 3438 M2 g-1), Al-MIL-101-NH2 (SBET = 3099 M2 g-1) and CAU-1 (SBET = 1492 M2 g-1), were synthesized and tested in the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with malononitrile and with Et cyanoacetate, resp.  It is shown that the expected products benzylidenemalononitrile (BzMN) and Et α-cyanocinnamate (EtCC) are formed with selectivities exceeding 99% and yields of 90 to 95% after 3 h (for BzMN).  Due to the very small pore windows of CAU-1 (0.3 to 0.4 nm) the reaction proceeds much slower over this catalyst in comparison to the amino-MIL-101 derivs., which possess open pore windows of up to 1.6 nm.  Moreover, the catalyst Al-MIL-101-NH2 is recyclable without significant loss of activity.
Selective Adsorption of CO2 from Light Gas Mixtures by Using a Structurally Dynamic Porous Coordination Polymer

Kauffman, Kristi L.; Culp, Jeffrey T.; Allen, Andrew J.; Espinal, Laura; Wong-Ng, Winnie; Brown, Thomas D.; Goodman, Angela; Bernardo, Mark P.; Pancoast, Russel J.; Chirdon, Danielle; Matranga, Christopher

A review.  Gas sepns. are important to many diverse areas of fossil energy including pre- and post-combustion CO2 capture and fuel cell applications.  The need for efficient gas purifn. processes has led to interest in adsorption-based sepns. and new sorbent materials.  Porous coordination polymers (PCP5), commonly referred to as metal-org. frameworks (MOF5), lend a great deal of structural versatility to such applications.  A combination of org. and inorg. building blocks, these multidimensional hosts can be tailored for selective adsorption of one guest over another through methods such as pore-size exclusion, mesh-size adjustable sieving, and guest-dependent structural dynamics.

This disparity owes to challenges assocd. with fabricating films of MOF materials, including poor substrate-film interactions, moisture sensitivity, and thermal/mech. instability. Crystallog. analyses of the adducts showed the solids to have monomeric structures with six-coordinate Bi(III). Electronic spectra and photochemical reactivity of bismuth corrole complexes
Reith, Lorenz M.; Himmelsbach, Markus; Schoefberger, Wolfgang; Knoer, Guenther

The first examples of bismuth complexes with meso-substituted corrole ligands are presented. In addn. to the intense intraligand (IL) absorption bands of the corrole macrocycle, this bismuth(III) complex displays metal-centered (MC) sp-transitions and metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transitions which show a substantial mixing with the intraligand absorption bands, thus resulting in an irregular hyper-type electronic spectrum.  Excitation of Bi-tpc in the spectral region of the MC-bands under ambient conditions leads to dioxygen activation and concomitant photochem. formation of the high-valent species (O=)BiV(tpc), an unprecedented example of a bismuth(V) tetrapyrrole complex.  As a potential reaction intermediate of this photoredox process, a labile hydroperoxo species (HOO)BiV(tpc)+ is also identified.  First results on the spectroscopic features and the chem. reactivity of (O=)BiV(tpc) are reported.  In soln. this neutral bismuth(V) species is in equil. with the corresponding protonated form (HO)BiV(tpc)+ carrying an axial hydroxo ligand.  Axial ligand exchange processes and the formation of adducts with solvent derived photoproducts are also identified in high-resoln. mass spectra of irradiated samples.  The mol. and electronic structures of the novel bismuth corrole systems are discussed in terms of supporting d. functional theory (DFT) calcns., which suggest an out-of-plane structure of the Bi-tpc and (O=)BiV(tpc) species.  Time-dependent DFT results are supporting the proposed assignment of electronic transitions obsd. in low- and high-valent bismuth tpc derivs.

WinGX suite for small-molecule single-crystal crystallography

The crystallog. problem:  The processing of a small-mol. structure from single-crystal X-ray or neutron diffraction data through structure soln. and refinement to prepn. of publication material is a well established and usually a reasonably automated procedure.  There are several excellent com. software packages, such as SHELXTL (Siemens, 1995) and TEXSAN (Mol. Structure Corporation, 1995), which provide all the necessary programs to undertake this procedure, but these packages are often quite expensive and usually tied to the sale of specific diffractometer hardware. The stereochemical activity or nonactivity of the 'inert' pair of electrons on lead(II) in relation to its complex stability and structural properties. Some considerations in ligand design
Hancock, Robert D.; Shaikjee, M. Salim; Dobson, Susan M.; Boeyens, Jan C. A.

The role of the lone pair of electrons on Pb(II) in its coordination geometry and complex stability is examd.  In a series of macrocyclic ligands where O donors are successively replaced by N donors, when 3 or 4 N atoms are present, there is a sudden marked increase in the rate of change of complex stability per N donor added.  This is attributed to a change from a stereochem. inactive lone pair with approx. ≤2 N donors present, to an active lone pair.  Below the transition point, the Pb(II) ion behaves as a large metal ion with rather ionic M-L bonding.  In this state it responds to added O-donor bearing groups as expected for such a metal ion.  Thus, the size-related selectivity patterns of Pb(II) with the ligand DAK-22 (4,7,13,16-tetraoxa-1,10-diazacyclooctadecane-N,N'-diacetate) are as expected for its size.  The protonation consts. and formation consts. of DAK-22 with several metal ions are reported.  For the complexes formed by 12-aneN4 (1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane) and 12-aneN3O (1-oxa-4,7,10-triazacyclododecane) the Pb(II) appears to have a stereochem. active lone pair.  Thus, when N-(2-hydroxypropyl) groups are added to 12-aneN4 and 12-aneN3O to give the ligands THP-12-aneN4 and THP-12-aneN3O, resp., the Pb(II) ion does not respond to the added hydroxyalkyl groups as might have been expected.  It behaves as a smaller more covalent ion, and a study of the formation consts. of THP-12-aneN4 and THP-12-aneN3O with Cu(II), Zn(II), Cd(II), Pb(II), Ca(II), Sr(II) and Ba(II) reveals lower than anticipated Pb/Zn selectivities.  A crystallog. study of [Pb(THP-12-aneN4)](NO3)2.PrOH reveals that there is space between the O donors for a stereochem. active lone pair, but the lack of shortening of the Pb-N bonds suggests that the lone pair is not active.  The complex crystallizes in the orthorhombic system, space group Pnma, with a 10.352(8), b 14.781(2), c 21.850(4) Å, Z = 4, R = 0.056.  Although the ligand THP-12-aneN4 has 4 chiral C atoms, the crystal structure suggests that only the RRRR and SSSS enantiomers of the free ligand are obtained after recrystn. from hexane.  The structure indicates that the [Pb(THP-12-aneN4)]2+ cations are disordered, with 50% site occupancy by the RRRR and by the SSSS conformer.

Aufbau Principle of Complex Open-Framework Structures of Metal Phosphates with Different Dimensionalities
Rao, C. N. R.; Natarajan, Srinivasan; Choudhury, Amitava; Neeraj, S.; Ayi, A. A.

A review with 27 refs.  Open-framework metal phosphates occur as 1-dimensional (1D) chains or ladders, two-dimensional (2D) layers, and complex three-dimensional (3D) structures.  Zero-dimensional monomers also were isolated recently.  These materials are traditionally prepd. by hydrothermal means, in the presence of org. amines, but the reactions of amine phosphates with metal ions provide a facile route for the synthesis, and also throw some light on the mode of formation of these fascinating architectures.  Careful studies of the transformations of monophasic zinc phosphates of well-characterized structures show that the 1-dimensional structures transform to 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional structures, while the 2-dimensional structures transform to 3-dimensional structures.  The zero-dimensional monomers transform to 1-dimensional, 2-dimensional, and 3-dimensional structures.  There is reason to believe that the 0-dimensional monomers, comprising four-membered rings, are the most basic structural units of the open-framework phosphates and that after an optimal precursor state, such as the ladder structure, is formed, further building may occur spontaneously.  Evidence for the occurrence of self-assembly in the formation of complex structures is provided by the presence of the structural features of the 1-dimensional starting material in the final products.  These observations constitute the beginning of the authors' understanding of the building-up principle of such complex structures.

Anjaneyulu, O.; Maddileti, D.; Kumara Swamy, K. C.

The reaction of triphenylbismuth [BiPh3] with several heterocyclic carboxylic acids was explored. Compd. 5 primarily exhibits a coordination no. of six with pentagonal pyramidal geometry at bismuth, but an addnl. weak Bi···O interaction in the direction of the lone pair of electrons is present.  This feature leads to a weakly bound dimer.  The use of pyridine as the solvent in a similar reaction, however, led to 7, in which all of the Bi-Ph bonds are cleaved.  In this compd., bismuth exhibits a coordination no. of eight and distorted dodecahedral geometry.  In compd. 8, the geometry around bismuth is primarily a pentagonal pyramid, however, clear-cut but weak secondary Bi···N interactions leading to a dimeric formulation are discernible in the structure.  The quinaldate compd. 9 exhibits a lower formal coordination no. of five for bismuth, with square pyramidal geometry, but again two secondary Bi···O interactions for each bismuth in the direction of the lone pair lead to a dimer.  A similar secondary Bi···O interaction involving furan oxygen is present in the furoate compd. 10, which is a polymeric chain (one dimensional coordination polymer).  Although the thiophene carboxylate 11 is also a polymeric chain, no Bi···S interactions are present.  Unlike the previously reported tetrameric biscarboxylate [PhBi(2-O2C-C5H3N)2]4, the thiophene carboxylate [PhBi(O2C-C4H3S)2]2 (12) is a dimer considering only primary interactions.  However, these dimers are arranged in such a way that there are secondary Bi···S interactions in the structure in the expected direction of the lone pair of electrons on bismuth.  Thus, these studies suggest that the stereochem. activity (or inactivity) of the bismuth lone pair of electrons need to be judged more cautiously.  TGA studies are consistent with the presence of Bi-Ph groups in all of the compds., except 7, as indicated by their formulas.
